photo.description: The Ephesus Theater in Selçuk Turkey was capable of holding 25,000 spectators. This open-air theater was used initially for drama, but during later Roman times gladiatorial combats were also held on its stage, with the first archaeological evidence of a gladiator graveyard found in May 2007. © www.tomjutte.tk

photo.description: This is a view on the Roman Theater at Ephesus, Selçuk, Turkey. Ephesus ( Ancient Greek Ἔφεσος, Ephesos; Turkish Efes) was the ancient Greek city Anatolia, and later a major Roman city, on the west coast of Asia Minor, near present-day Selçuk, Izmir Province, Turkey. It was one of the twelve cities of the Ionian League during the Classical Greek era. In the Roman period, Ephesus had a population of more than 250,000 in the 1st century BC, which also made it one of the largest cities in the Mediterranean world. Ephesus (Efes) in Turkey is an UNESCO World Heritage Site. © www.tomjutte.tk
photo.tags: webshots travel sunset nature water sea sun vakantie turkey türkiye sony cybershot turkije holiday roman efes theater selçuk ephesus anatolia architecture ruin ruins unesco unescoworldheritagesite
photo.title: Ephesus Selçuk, Turkey - 2456

photo.description: The city of Ephesus in Turkey was famed for the Temple of Artemis (completed around 550 BC), which was destroyed by the Goths in 263. The emperor Constantine I rebuilt much of the city and erected a new public bath. © www.tomjutte.tk

photo.description: This open-air theater was used initially for drama, but during later Roman times gladiatorial combats were also held on its stage and which was capable of holding 25,000 spectators. The Ephesus Theater, Selçuk Turkey is believed to be the largest outdoor theater in the ancient world. © www.tomjutte.tk

photo.description: Particularly since plumbing is a fairly modern convenience in Europe and the USA (often added only in the 19th or even 20th century), I always find it interesting to see the extensive city plumbing networks of ancient Greek and Roman cities. These granite cubes were used for connections for major water lines, which were generally made of terracotta (baked clay) but would also be carved of granite for high pressure water mains.
photo.tags: archeology turkey ancient upload ssturkey2012 ephesus
photo.title: Ancient Plumbing

photo.description: St Paul once preached here. It is now the venue for performances during the Ephesus Festival of Culture and Art. It has a diameter of 50 metres and a capacity of 25,000 spectators. photo.description: The great theatre within the ancient Roman city of Ephesus. Late in the afternoon we were the only ones left. Stunning place, stunning light and, well, awesome
photo.title: Ephesus Roman Theatre

photo.description: This image shows the main theater of Ephesus as viewed from the road to the harbor. Before it was knocked down by earthquakes, the three-story stone backdrop to the stage would have blocked out most of the seats and instead presented an elaborate facade of arches, alcoves and statuary. The theater dates back to around the 3rd century BC but was extensively remodeled and expanded during the reigns of the Roman Emperors Domitian (81-96 AD) and Trajan (98-117 AD).
photo.title: Central Theater of Ephesus

photo.description: This road used to lead to the harbour of Ephesus. However, since the harbour is now located miles away from the city, this precipitated the end of Ephesus as a city.

photo.description: Ephesos stones
photo.title: imgp5001

photo.description: In ancient days, the broad colonnaded street connected central Ephesus to its port. In typical Classical fashion, a roof once connected the columns to the solid wall on each side. The wall itself was actually the front of the continuous series of stores and shops that lined the street. From its earliest days (around 7,000 BC), Ephesus was connected to the sea. The road to the port was enlarged and turned into a typical Greek market street in the 2nd century BC, when King Attalos II improved the natural harbor by building stone docks and quays. The various earthquakes that struck the region not only damaged the cities, the shook up the mountains and thereby greatly increased the silting of rivers. By the 3rd century AD, a canal had to be built do connect Ephesus to the sea shore, which was moving farther and farther away. By 1,000 AD, Ephesus had lost its importance as a port.
photo.tags: archeology turkey ancient upload ssturkey2012 ephesus
photo.title: Ephesus Harbor Road
